i'm getting this error http://pastebin.ubuntu.com/422041/
why can't i extract this in ubuntu 9.1 x64?
because that command has both -x for extract and -c for create new archive, which is nonsensical.
if you're trying to extract that tar.gz, remove the -c /opt off the end
now i'm getting this error after removing the "-c /opt" http://pastebin.ubuntu.com/422043/
you're not on the desktop. Like ubottu said, we don't support xampp installs.
the webpage probably meant -C instead of -c
ha ha i actually just did that too when installing the ubuntu guest OS additions
not really. that would give apache2 (or your httpd in general) sudo permissions, which would be an issue if someone exploited a vulnerability in apache2.
so is that not the way to use ssh/sftp? cuz a few guides i found said to do that, but it seemed like a security risk
It is a security risk. I use ssh, sftp, and apache2, and am not sure why you'd want to do that :\
do you not use a user specifically for /var/www access?
I added my user account to the www-data group.
which is probably not ideal either, but at least then you're not giving sudo access to a public-facing daemon
SFTP is not SSH + FTP.
when i use filezilla and choose, sftp -ssh it connects fine for my main user, and i'm guesing this is secure right?
sftp is a protocol provided by openssh-server that has nothing to do with your FTP server.
and yes, sftp is secure
from what i've learnd ftp goes thru the ssh tunnel, hence the traffic is secure right?
I just said SFTP is secure. SFTP is not FTP through an SSH tunnel, it's an entirely separate protocol from FTP.
